post_text:
Dawn Haun Recognized for CCPS Media Support
At the September 14th School Board meeting, Dawn Haun was recognized for her support of our local school board’s work and for the public school students in Caroline County. The Caroline County School Board recommended Dawn Haun to be recognized by Virginia School Board Association’s Media Honor Roll. Ms. Haun is a journalist for the Free Lance Star. CCPS wants to personally thank Dawn for her commitment to the students in our division. Her work has aided in focusing on the goal of providing the best public schools we can for the children who attend. On behalf of the VSBA and CCPS, we thank you!

CCPS Welcomes Heather Gallion - 2nd Grade Teacher at Lewis and Clark Elementary School!

Hello! My name is Heather Gallion and I am teaching second grade at Lewis and Clark Elementary School this year. I grew up in Caroline, and attended Caroline County Public Schools K-12. I earned my Master’s Degree in Elementary Education from Liberty University. I am so excited to be teaching alongside some of my own teachers, and to be giving back to the community that raised me!

post_text:
Due to our August 24th school start date for secondary schools and the September 8th start date for elementary schools, the Caroline County School Board approved the following revisions to the 2020-2021 Instructional Calendar. The following days will now be full school days:
Monday, October 12
Monday, January 4
Friday, February 12
Friday, April 2
Wednesday, May 26 is still the last day of school, but now is a full day and not a half day.

The approved revisions will satisfy the core instructional time requirements defined by the Code of Virginia for grades Prek-8 and bring Caroline High School closer to meeting the required 140 clock hours for verified credit. We thank the School Board for approving the additional 4.5 instructional days as Caroline County Public Schools continues to empower the next generation of learners, thinkers, and leaders.

post_text:
CCPS Welcomes Hailey Seal - 1st Grade Teacher at Madison Elementary School!

My name is Hailey Seal and this is my first year teaching in Caroline County Public Schools! I have taught third grade in Henrico for the past few years, but I am beyond excited to teach first grade at Madison Elementary. Teaching is my passion. I love to be creative, supportive, and silly in my classroom-- I will do anything to get students engaged! I graduated Cum Laude with my degree in Elementary Education from VCU. Prior to that, I graduated from Caroline High School (Go Cavaliers!). It feels good to be back home in Caroline and I am humbled and honored to give back to the school system that fueled my love for education.

CCPS families - just a reminder about the CCPS IT Device Care Center: Tuesdays from 8am until 10am and Thursdays from 2pm until 4pm.

The PK-12 Care Center operates at the Caroline High School campus in the new gym parking lot. Per COVID guidelines, please remain in your vehicle while being assisted. Upon arrival, please turn on your vehicle’s flashers, and someone will come to assist you.

Please remember to bring chargers with any devices you need serviced, so that staff can make sure all device parts are working for your students.

post_text: Just a reminder that per 2019 state regulation governing pre-Labor Day school openings, CCPS is required to close on the Friday and Monday of Labor Day weekend. This law is not applicable to all pre-Labor day divisions, only those beginning early starts prior 2015. Looking forward to welcoming back all students (PK-12) on Tuesday, 9/8. Enjoy the holiday weekend.

post_text:
Caroline County Schools Needs Your Help!

We are excited to announce our new Family Engagement Bus as a resource for our Caroline students and families! We are working diligently to secure funding to rewrap the bus and purchase supplies and educational materials for students and parents so we can begin traveling around the Caroline Community!
Please help us name our new bus by submitting suggestions and ideas to Andrea Ross, Supervisor of Federal Programs, via email @ aross@ccps.us no later than Friday, September 4th.
Once we have several options for a name, we will send out a google form for the students, staff and parents to vote!

post_text: Caroline Historic Homes is hosting an online Art Exhibit & Silent Auction with five artists donating to five charities. We are pleased to announce that artist, Helen Butler, has chosen CCPS Food Service as the recipient of 25% of the proceeds from the sale of the Hampton Manor painting (pictured bottom right), once home to the one and only Salvador Dali. The online bidding process can be easily accessed at thepaintedhorse.org. Bidding began Aug. 7 and runs through Friday, Sept. 11.

post_text:
As we are halfway through our first week of VIRTUAL+ learning for our middle and high school students, we wanted to provide a quick reminder that although students are not engaged in “live” synchronous instruction from teachers on Wednesdays, they should continue to work on assigned asynchronous assignments. While teachers are utilizing Wednesdays for critical collaboration, planning, and training, they will also remain available by email throughout the day and by phone during their office hours to answer any questions.

Moving forward, teachers may also use Wednesdays to provide select students with remedial supports as well as access to CTE lab experiences as appropriate.

Moving forward, teachers may also use Wednesdays to provide select students with remedial supports as well as access to CTE lab experiences as appropriate.

shared_text:
Parent Educational Advocacy Training Center (PEATC)
August 25 at 10:05 AM ·

PEATC is excited to be providing IEP consultations with students!

To help students feel more confident about participating in their IEP meetings and to ensure that their needs, choices, and preferences and what they want to do after high school is accurately reflected in their IEP, PEATC is offering individual consult meetings with students. These consultations will help student participants better understand what is in the IEP and how it relates to achieving their goals and dreams.

WHAT'S IN MY IEP? | SEPTEMBER 3, 2020 | 20 Minute Time Slots

REGISTER: https://whatsinmyiep.eventbrite.com

While parents and guardians are encouraged to listen in, the conversation will be with the student.

Only register for one time slot.

Reminder! If your CCPS provided hotspot is inoperable due to your home’s distance to a cell tower, please drop it off tomorrow or Thursday at the CCPS Device Care Center. We will be operating at Caroline High School on every Tuesday from 8 - 10 a.m. and Thursdays from 2 - 4 p.m. to service all CCPS devices. This is a curbside service model, so no need to get out of your vehicle!

If internet access is still needed, instructional staff will be on hand to discuss hub options for your child needing internet support.

post_text:
As CCPS students begin their VIRTUAL+ learning, CCPS IT will open the "CCPS Device Care Center" starting on August 25th to assist in supporting students with devices in need of repair. This will include Chromebook, iPad, and Hotspot support. The "CCPS Device Care Center" will provide service in the lobby area of the Caroline High School's new gym.

The CCPS Device Care Center hours of operation will be Tuesdays from 8-10am and Thursdays from 2-4pm to help accommodate all CCPS families.

The CCPS Device Care Center will also adhere to all COVID guidelines and serve everyone via curbside pickup.

post_text:
On Friday, August 21, the CCPS School Board approved an adjusted start date for Elementary only. Due to the new increase in demand for technology, students in grades PreK-5 will begin school on Tuesday, September 8. Elementary teachers will be reaching out to their students (online or on the phone) during these two weeks to develop relationships and orient students to devices and programs.

More information will be forthcoming regarding iPad distribution. 840 devices will be delivered to CCPS on 9/3 and distribution will occur prior to 9/8.

Grades 6-12 will begin as originally approved on Monday, August 24. Stop by the secondary only overage distribution (limited hotspot supply remaining) at CHS today from 11-1 if technology support is needed.

post_text:
Caroline County Schools Needs Your Help!

We are excited to announce our new Family Engagement Bus as a resource for our Caroline students and families! We are working diligently to secure funding to rewrap the bus and purchase supplies and educational materials for students and parents so we can begin traveling around the Caroline Community!

Please help us name our new bus by submitting suggestions and ideas to Andrea Ross, Supervisor of Federal Programs, via email @ aross@ccps.us no later than Friday, September 4th.

Once we have several options for a name, we will send out a google form for the students, staff and parents to vote!

The CCPS School Board will be hosting a Special Called School Board Meeting this afternoon (Friday, August 21, 2020) at 4:30 at Caroline Middle School. The purpose of the special called meeting will be to discuss a proposed amendment to the elementary VIRTUAL+ start date due to newly presented parental device requests far exceeding the recorded needs (survey and principal documented adjustments). Please see the email that was sent last evening (August 21, 2020) to all CCPS families for related information: https://docs.google.com/document/d/18yW5Fk4bEY_CfxNEdypbxYn4HqHy_3Qtu8Xpj7Z1gH0/edit?usp=sharing

In-person attendance will be capped at 100 people to ensure proper COVID-19 procedures can be implemented. If unable to attend, public comment may be submitted via email to lstevens@ccps.us no later than 3:00 p.m. today. Emails submitted by 3:00 will be read aloud during public comment and are limited to three-minutes.

post_text: Do you spend hours filling out school opening paperwork each year? Caroline County Public Schools is pleased to announce that the school division is using a new online student registration/annual forms system called LINQ. LINQ provides a parent/guardian with the opportunity to electronically update demographic information such as address, phone number, and emergency contacts… and the system populates this information on all forms! Additionally, you may digitally sign school opening forms such as code of conduct document, acceptable use of technology, web access, and the student digital citizenship agreement - no more paper copies!

post_text:
UPDATE: School divisions across the United States are experiencing widespread delays in the delivery of technology, and unfortunately, CCPS is no exception. We were notified this week that our CCPS hotspots and iPad cords will not arrive until early next week. As a result, the previously published device distribution dates have been altered to reflect Wed.-Fri. We are sorry for any inconvenience this may cause.

As a reminder, CCPS will be initially distributing Chromebooks, iPads, and Hotspots by need (per parent survey data/principal database). Once all backordered iPads and Chromebooks arrive, we will host a second distribution period to achieve a divisionwide 1:1 environment for all students.

Please see the flyer for distribution locations, times, and tips!

As a result, the previously published device distribution dates have been altered to reflect Wed.-Fri. We are sorry for any inconvenience this may cause.

As a reminder, CCPS will be initially distributing Chromebooks, iPads, and Hotspots by need (per parent survey data/principal database). Once all backordered iPads and Chromebooks arrive, we will host a second distribution period to achieve a divisionwide 1:1 environment for all students.

Please see the flyer for distribution locations, times, and tips!

post_text:
Good afternoon, CCPS families! The School Nutrition Department is pleased to announce the 20-21 plans for providing back to school meals to all students. Under the current VIRTUAL+ return to learn model, the school division has been approved to provide meals free of charge to all CCPS students.

Students eligible to attend in person (select SPED, English Language Learners, and no Internet access) will receive breakfast and lunch in school on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday. These students will also receive bagged meals on Tuesday for at home use on Wednesday.

Students learning remotely from home can pick up meals each week on Wednesday. Pickup sites will be located at BGES, LCES, MES & CMS from 7:30-9:30 AM and 10:30 AM-12:30 PM daily. To support working families, CCPS will also offer a PM pick up at CHS from 4:00-6:00 PM. Remote learners will receive 10 meals (5 breakfasts and 5 lunches) every Wednesday.

We look forward to providing this valuable service to all of our Caroline families! #OneCaroline

post_text:
CCPS encourages our school community to engage in education, awareness, and ADVOCACY! To support proactive pandemic planning and heighten response capabilities, the school division requested that the Board of Supervisor chairman consider the following three agenda items for inclusion on the August 11 BOS meeting: 1) provide the BOS with a brief CCPS Return to Learn update during the information portion of the meeting, 2) request the reappropriation of the school division’s year-end monies from FY18, FY19, and FY20 to support one time costs associated with the school division’s COVID-19 safety mitigation and reopening expenses, 3) strengthen communication and collaboration through a commitment to quarterly Joint Board Meetings (CCPS and BOS). NONE of these requests were included on the posted August 11, 2020 BOS Meeting Agenda.

Please email or phone your Board of Supervisor by Tuesday afternoon or join CCPS at the BOS meeting on Tuesday evening to express your support of Caroline students, staff, and the school community. Your voice is very much needed and appreciated.
#OneCaroline

post_text: Some great self care reminders as we continue to navigate pandemic times!

post_text:
Hello CCPS Families,

CCPS IT will begin deploying devices the week of August 17 through August 21 to those students in need. This includes iPads to our PreK-2nd graders and Chromebooks to our 3rd graders and up. A schedule with more information will be released next week.

Hotspots will also be deployed to households (1 per household only) needing them to participate in the Virtual+ start to our school year. The families that indicated on the parent survey that they have no access to Broadband will be primary recipients with those with limited or unreliable access being served in a secondary capacity.

We ask that if your 3rd grade or higher student has access to personal computers, laptops, and broadband Internet, please utilize them during this time. This will help ensure that all CCPS students are equipped to start this unprecedented school year. #OneCaroline

CCPS IT extends our thanks to all those that choose to help!

post_text:
The CCPS Preschool Program is recruiting for the 2020-2021 school year!

School begins on August 24th and we are continuing to take applications for preschool. If your child will be 4 years old before September 30th, please obtain a pre-application from the CCPS website or contact your zone school for assistance. Completed pre-applications may be emailed to csimms@ccps.us or dropped off at your home school.

To date, we have 40 remaining spots open. At a recent meeting the School Board approved a Virtual + instructional model for PK-12 thru October 8th. CCPS is committed to ensuring a positive, engaging, and developmentally appropriate virtual experience for your preschool student. We look forward to receiving your application.

post_text:
Dear CCPS Family,

For weeks, staff, students, and parents have anticipated the School Board’s approval of the 2020-2021 Return to Learn plan. I am pleased to report that at this afternoon’s special called board meeting, the Caroline County School Board approved the VIRTUAL+ instructional delivery model for the first quarter (8/24-10/8). After productive deliberation, the Board’s unanimous vote (6-0) reflected their collective commitment to the health and well-being of all students and staff. [ 391 more words ]
http://www.ccps.us/2020/07/ccps-board-approves-return-to-learn-plan/

Dear CCPS Family,

For weeks, staff, students, and parents have anticipated the School Board’s approval of the 2020-2021 Return to Learn plan. I am pleased to report that at this afternoon’s special called board meeting, the Caroline County School Board approved the VIRTUAL+ instructional delivery model for the first quarter (8/24-10/8). After productive deliberation, the Board’s unanimous vote (6-0) reflected their collective commitment to the health and well-being of all students and staff. [ 391 more words ]
http://www.ccps.us/2020/07/ccps-board-approves-return-to-learn-plan/

Special School Board meeting for CCPS on July 30, 2020

CCPS Special Board Meeting - July 30, 2020

post_text:
The CCPS School Board will hold a Special Called School Board Meeting on Thursday, July 30 at 3:00PM at Caroline Middle School, 13325 Devils Three Jump Road, Milford, VA 22514 to review and approve the 2020-2021 Return to Learn plan.

The meeting will be streamed live on our CCPS Facebook page. All virtual attendees submitting public comments must email the School Board Clerk, Lisa Stevens, by 5PM Wednesday, July 29 at lstevens@ccps.us. All comments received via email by the deadline will be read aloud during the public comment section of the agenda. The meeting agenda can be accessed on Boarddocs through the CCPS website.

For those in attendance: Social distancing will be enforced and face coverings are required. A health screening and temperature checks will be done prior to being admitted into the meeting. Due to social distancing, only 100 seats are available.

shared_text:
Bowling Green Farmers Market
July 10 at 9:38 AM ·

In Fredericksburg, Spotsylvania, King George and Caroline, the match has been increased from $30 to $50, meaning that a SNAP customer can receive a $1 to $1 match up to $50. Spend $50 in EBT, get $50 fruits and vegetables free!
-Pandemic-EBT is welcome! P-EBT cards have been widely distributed in the region. We encourage all families with P-EBT to use these benefits at the farmers market to get additional free fruits and vegetables for their families. This also helps the farmers tremendously, and supporting farmers is a concern for many right now.
-Many markets have implemented safety protocols to protect customers and vendors, limiting the number of people who have touched the food between farm and table. Produce is abundant and gorgeous this time of year, and the farmers appreciate your business. Farmers markets remain great places to shop!

Examples of citizenship are becoming more and more commonplace given the current COVID-19 status and its effects on society. Use iMovie to create a video or Google Slides to create a slideshow displaying examples of citizenship that you have been a part of, experienced, or observed.

Get ready, set, go, PRACTICE CITIZENSHIP! #OneCaroline

post_text:
Join CCPS for this week’s 5C Challenge! Let’s unite as a community to demonstrate how we Communicate, Collaborate, and think Creatively & Critically to display amazing #OneCaroline Citizenship!

The focus for today’s 5 C Challenge is Creativity:

Gather three (3) different color sets of beads in your home and a string to make a bracelet spelling your name using the binary code alphabet. Use one color to signify spaces for your letters on your bracelet. Use another color to signify a zero (0), and the final color to signify a one (1). The zeros (0) and ones (1) will be used to create the letters. For example A is 1000001. So one may use two (2) reds to signify the ones (1) and five (5) blacks to signify the zeros (0). So the pattern for A is red, black, black, black, black, black, red.

Get ready, set, go, CREATE! #OneCaroline

The spring and summer months are the most dangerous times for teens on the road. In 2019, 7,903 crashes involved a teen driver ages 15-20. Parents share this with your teens to commit to driving safely this summer by signing our Arrive Alive pledge. It'll take less than a minute and you'll be entered to win a $50 Amazon gift card! They will also receive an Arrive Alive Kit that can help them earn extra entries for the drawing.
To sign, go to: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdLpfi_5PC0U906dpoDw8yF8RrSFbyEXhmiAOIIUcm73hWrag/viewform

post_text:
Join CCPS for this week’s 5C Challenge! Let’s unite as a community to demonstrate how we Communicate, Collaborate, and think Creatively & Critically to display amazing #OneCaroline Citizenship!

The focus for today’s 5 C Challenge is Collaboration.

Collaborate with a family member on a weekly nutrition challenge counting daily calories consumed, total grams of fats, carbohydrates and proteins consumed using food nutrition labels. Using Google Sheets, design a spreadsheet to track your data as well as your family member’s. Use the formula function to calculate weekly totals for nutrients and calories. Use the average formula function to calculate daily averages.

Think of a family member that you have not been able to see given our current society’s conditions with social distancing. Address an envelope, add a stamp, and send the letter to that family member.

post_text:
We appreciate the over 1700 responses we received from the first Return-to-Learn survey. In order to further refine our plans, CCPS has emailed the R2L Parent Survey 2.0 to learn the preferred instructional option for each of your children by grade and school, Internet needs for virtual instruction, and your household’s transportation needs. It may be helpful prior to completing the survey to refer to the newly released CCPS R2L website (http://r2l.blogs.ccps.us/). Click on the menu and then “Delivery Models” to read more about the draft instructional options for 20-21 (virtual or hybrid).

To meet the VDOE instructional plan submission deadline for CCPS (15 business days prior to school opening, July 20), please submit one survey per student no later than noon on Tuesday, July 7.

Thanks for your participation and take a peek at your email for the survey link.

CCPS has been working diligently since school ended in May to create a safe and effective instructional plan for the 2020-21 school year. The link below shows the timeline of what has been accomplished thus far and the remaining action steps in developing our Return-to-Learn plan. Notice the Community Forum on July 14 at CMS. We would love to have parents, students, and staff participate in this meeting to provide input in refining our plan. The plan will be finalized, forwarded to the VDOE, and posted on the CCPS website by July 20, with the first day of school occurring on August 10.

Former CHS baseball player, Bill Wojcik, was named State Player of the Year by the Virginia Sports Information Directors College Division. Bill graduated from Caroline in 2017 and plays at Marymount University. Congratulations Bill!

post_text: Congratulations to Mrs. Darlene Keener, CCPS Behavior Coordinator, on her acceptance to the statewide 2020-2021 Cohort of the Aspiring Special Education Leaders Academy. This is a great opportunity for Darlene to have been selected to represent the division, to meet leaders in special education throughout the state, and to learn of new initiatives and ideas to better help our students with special needs. Caroline County Public Schools congratulates Mrs. Keener on her commitment to special education and on her acceptance in the cohort .

post_text:
Today marks Juneteenth, the 155th celebration and commemoration of the end of slavery in the United States, held annually across the nation on June 19. Governor Northam announced a proposal to make Juneteenth a state holiday for the Commonwealth of Virginia.

On Thursday, June 18, the CCPS School Board approved an amendment to the 19-20 and 20-21 school calendar to observe the proposed Juneteenth holiday by closing all CCPS schools and offices. CCPS employees are currently working the summer schedule which reflects four, ten-hour workdays with Fridays off. As a result, Juneteenth 2020 will be observed by CCPS on Monday, June 22. Please note, summer food distribution will continue at the previously identified sites on Monday.
text:
Today marks Juneteenth, the 155th celebration and commemoration of the end of slavery in the United States, held annually across the nation on June 19. Governor Northam announced a proposal to make Juneteenth a state holiday for the Commonwealth of Virginia.

On Thursday, June 18, the CCPS School Board approved an amendment to the 19-20 and 20-21 school calendar to observe the proposed Juneteenth holiday by closing all CCPS schools and offices. CCPS employees are currently working the summer schedule which reflects four, ten-hour workdays with Fridays off. As a result, Juneteenth 2020 will be observed by CCPS on Monday, June 22. Please note, summer food distribution will continue at the previously identified sites on Monday.

post_text: Return to Learn (R2L) task force planning is well underway! Stay tuned for regular R2L updates beginning in early July!

post_text:
The Caroline County School Board appointed Ms. Rochelle Brown as Assistant Principal of Caroline Middle School at their meeting on June 18, 2020.
Ms. Brown graduated from Virginia Commonwealth University with a Bachelor’s Degree in Business Administration and Management. She also holds a Master’s Degree in Administration and Supervision from Regent University. Ms. Brown is currently a Dean of Students for Chesterfield County Public Schools. Serving in this leadership role for the past two years has enabled her to develop strong communication, interpersonal, and organizational skills. Ms. Brown coordinated professional development activities in Restorative Practices and Positive Behavior Intervention and Support (PBIS), initiated a Monday Mentor attendance program and led the School Safety Committee. Ms. Brown taught at Chesterfield County Public Schools before accepting the Dean position. Caroline County is excited to welcome Ms. Brown to the Caroline Middle School team for the 2020-2021 school year.

Caroline County is excited to welcome Ms. Brown to the Caroline Middle School team for the 2020-2021 school year.

post_text:
The Caroline County School Board appointed Mrs. Kristi Thomas as Assistant Principal of Bowling Green Elementary School at their meeting on June 18, 2020.
Mrs. Thomas graduated from James Madison University with her Bachelor’s of Science degree in Sociology and received her Masters of Arts in Reading from Grand Canyon University. She is also pursuing her Doctorate of Education in Organizational Leadership K-12, from Grand Canyon University. Mrs. Thomas is currently serving as the Reading Specialist for Bowling Green Elementary School where she has been instrumental in contributing to the school’s success. Prior to accepting that position, she was a teacher at BGE from 2016-2019. Caroline County is excited to welcome Mrs. Thomas to the Bowling Green Elementary School team for the 2020-2021 school year.

Students and staff are in their third week of Virtual Summer Academy- check out some of the things they are doing together while apart...
Mrs. Fletcher’s class created Setting Description, Graffiti Style: highlighting the descriptions to make schema connections to the story.
All things integers were at the forefront discussions with Ms. Mateer. Students utilized the multi-user whiteboard to show off what they know!
Last Thursday, Mr. Trainum reported it was a great end to another week. “ We had our midterm test today!!! It went smooth, great bunch of kids to work with!!!!”
#OneCaroline

post_text:
Join CCPS for this week’s 5C Challenge! Let’s unite as a community to demonstrate how we Communicate, Collaborate, and think Creatively & Critically to display amazing #OneCaroline Citizenship!

Today’s 5C Challenge focus is Communication.
Tell a story by making a silent movie. Your story must have a beginning, a problem in the middle and an ending with a solution. Try to convey the main character’s feelings throughout using only body language. If you don’t have a recording device available put on a show for your family.

Get ready, set, go, COMMUNICATE! #OneCaroline

post_text: Need to find a healthy balance for your mental and physical health? Take a trip to the beach! Vitamin D from the sun mixed with the salt and sound of the ocean act as a natural mood boosting antidepressant, detoxifies the mind and body, builds up the immune system, fights insomnia, and helps to fight health conditions such as heart disease, high blood pressure, osteoporosis and asthma. The beach also provides many outlets for physical activity, such as walking, swimming, paddleboarding, pickleball, and even yoga (Rowen Foltz providing a demonstration.) Be sure to protect your skin from harmful prolonged exposure to UV rays by wearing sunscreen and remember to drink water to stay hydrated!

Be sure to protect your skin from harmful prolonged exposure to UV rays by wearing sunscreen and remember to drink water to stay hydrated!

post_text:
Caroline County Public Schools Announces Danny Younce as
Pupil Transportation Coordinator

Caroline County Public Schools is excited to announce Danny Younce will be joining the Transportation team as the Pupil Transportation Coordinator, filling the position vacated by Mr. Erick Childs. He will begin on 6/16/2020. Mr. Younce attended Germanna Community College with a focus on business and career development coursework and is a member of the Virginia Association of Pupil Transportation. He served as a bus driver for Stafford County before attaining the position of Route Manager for Prince William County Schools in 2014. Mr. Younce plans to use his interpersonal and organizational skills to assist the transportation department and build upon the goals.

He served as a bus driver for Stafford County before attaining the position of Route Manager for Prince William County Schools in 2014. Mr. Younce plans to use his interpersonal and organizational skills to assist the transportation department and build upon the goals.

post_text:
Caroline County Public Schools Announces Natalee Tuck as Special Education Compliance Coordinator

Caroline County Public Schools is excited to announce Mrs.Natalee Tuck will be joining the Special Education team as Compliance Coordinator, filling the position vacated by Mr. James O’Reilly. Mrs. Tuck will begin on 8/1/2020. She graduated with a Bachelor’s Degree in Sociology from Virginia Commonwealth University and earned her Master’s Degree in Special Education from Grand Canyon University. Mrs. Tuck has worked as a Special Education Teacher for Caroline County Public Schools since 2004. She has also served as the Special Education and Child Study/Eligibility Chairperson from 2006-2014 for Lewis and Clark Elementary School. CCPS welcomes Natalee Tuck as the Special Education Compliance Coordinator.

post_text:
On Sunday, June 7, the Caroline community united in support of listening, learning, and loving. Gathered together on the courthouse lawn, faith leaders, CCSO, CCPS, Caroline’s Promise, the commonwealth attorney, the NAACP, the YMCA, students, families, and neighbors collectively committed themselves to meaningful and sustained action.

Thank you to the CCPS school board, superintendent, division leaders, teachers, staff, and families who joined “hip to hip and heart to heart” in solidarity for Black men, women, and children. #OneCaroline #LetsGetToWork #DifferenceMakers

Caroline County Public Schools would like to announce that on May 28, 2020, Mr. Darin Thompson was appointed principal of Varina High School in Henrico County. Mr. Thompson will begin his new position on July 1, 2020. We thank Mr. Thompson for his servant leadership at Caroline Middle School during the 19-20 school year and wish him well as he transitions to employment within his county of residence.

post_text:
If your child has free or reduced school meal benefits, you can expect to receive $367 per eligible student through the Pandemic EBT (P-EBT) Act.
The Department of Social Services will provide meal replacement benefits through SNAP, known as “Pandemic EBT”, for households with children who attend a school that’s closed and who would otherwise receive free or reduced-price meals.
Families are not required to be current SNAP participants or complete an application to qualify for P-EBT benefits. Qualifying families will be automatically enrolled in the program.
Families are encouraged to visit http://pebtva.com for more information about the P-EBT program and answers to frequently asked questions.

Join CCPS for this week’s 5C Challenge! Let’s unite as a community to demonstrate how we Communicate, Collaborate, and think Creatively & Critically to display amazing #OneCaroline Citizenship!
The focus for today’s 5 C Challenge is Creativity:
As you have studied history, you often learn of times where illnesses and diseases change the course of history. You are living in a time such as that now. What will future generations want to learn about 2020? Use Google Photos, We Video, iMovie or something similar to document this historical time. Be sure to include details that would help someone living years from now understand what it was like to be living in 2020. Get ready, set, go, CREATE! OneCaroline

post_text:
The focus for today’s 5C Challenge is Collaboration.
Watch the following video on Finding Balance in the Digital World https://youtu.be/MkwmD6OQrWQ. Think about the following questions… What are some of the benefits of being connected 24/7? What are some of the benefits of doing things offline… that don’t involve digital media? When you are not online, what activities add something fun or important to your life? What challenges might come up that would make it hard to successfully become ‘unplugged’? Try a new tool, Animaker https://app.animaker.com/dashboard, to respond to the above questions and teach others about the importance of a balanced digital world. It is free and easy to create an account (remember with your parent’s permission and account information if you are under 13).
Get ready, set, go, COLLABORATE! #OneCaroline

Today’s 5C Challenge focus is Communication.
Email, text, or call a friend to work on this together. Watch the following video on My Social Media Life https://youtu.be/fBWQTb5WLg4. Open the following document on Social Media https://docs.google.com/document/d/1etoKnxiIZfb8COnn_ivBrdaOFH7AzueExYtTlFXp790/copy: Good? Bad? Both? and complete stating if you agree or disagree. Lastly, use Google Slides to try to persuade someone to shift their thinking about social media. What could you and your partner do to solve the problem together and get the best out of social media?
Get ready, set, go, COMMUNICATE! #OneCaroline

post_text:
As the summer begins, Caroline County Public Schools will be adjusting the hours and locations of our emergency meal service. The last day of the current “Grab & Go” program was May 20th. There will be no meal service on Monday, May 25th for Memorial Day.

Beginning Wednesday, May 27th through Monday, June 29th , we will have changes to the locations and meal distribution times. Bowling Green Elementary and Lewis & Clark Elementary Schools will serve from 10 a.m. to 12 p.m. Madison Elementary School and our Dawn location at Second Mount Zion Baptist Church will serve from 10:30 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. We will continue with three days per week service for meal pick-up on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. “Grab & Go” breakfasts and lunches will be served curbside during the planned times, to all children 18 years of age or younger on a first-come, first-served basis.

Have a great summer!

Students grades 6 through 11 should keep their chromebooks during the summer break for use in educational enrichment. Parents or students who opt to turn in their chromebooks, may do so during normal Care Center hours. Please remember to submit a ticket before dropping off your student's chromebook.

Graduating seniors must return Chromebooks and chargers during their assigned graduation process during the week of May 26-29. There will be technology staff onsite during graduation to collect and inspect turned in equipment. If your graduate is not participating in the upcoming graduation event, please bring your chromebook to the Chromebook Care Center.

If your 6th through 11th grade student is moving out of county over the summer, please bring your chromebook to the Chromebook Care Center.

http://ts.blogs.ccps.us/resources/it-service-desk/

post_text:
In recognition of Mental Health Awareness Month, we are spotlighting our current staff who support employee and student wellness.
My name is Valeta Dixon and I am a School Social Worker. I graduated from West Virginia Wesleyan College with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Social Work and Psychology and earned my Master of Social Work degree from Virginia Commonwealth University. I have worked in Caroline County for over twenty years and currently serve Lewis and Clark Elementary, Madison Elementary and Caroline High School as part of their support staff. My main responsibilities include: helping support the academic, behavioral, social/emotional needs of students through general education or special education avenues as part of the child study, eligibility and IEP teams within each school, meeting with families to complete Sociocultural Assessments and obtaining adaptive behavior information and identifying and linking students and families for community-based services to help provide support.

This is what I do, and I appreciate what you do! #OneCaroline

post_text:
Do you have a budget passion point?

A public hearing will be held on May 26, 2020 beginning at 7:30 p.m. or soon thereafter in order for the Board of Supervisors to receive comments from the public on the proposed FY21 budget. Due to the public health threat caused by the novel coronavirus the Board of Supervisors have adjusted the format for the public to be able to make a comment on the budget for the public hearing. Specific details of how to participate in the public hearing on the proposed FY21 budget can be found in the Notice of Public Hearing located on the county website at https://co.caroline.va.us/DocumentCenter/View/4113/Caroline-County-Notice-of-Public-Hearing-for-Proposed-Tax-Rates-May-26-2020.

The County Administrator provided an updated proposed FY21 Budget to the Board of Supervisors at the May 5, 2020 meeting. The County Administrator's proposed FY21 budget has a zero dollar increase of the county transfer to the School's operational budget and School's CIP budget in the amount of $901,047.

post_text:
In recognition of Mental Health Awareness Month, we are spotlighting our current staff who support employee and student wellness.
Hello! My name is Laura Mosonyi and I am an occupational therapist. You may see me throughout the county working with some of our special needs students. I help them discover their strengths, improve their skills, and develop adaptations so that they can access the curriculum and be successful in the school environment. I often help students develop improved sensory processing skills, visual-motor integration skills, motor coordination, and self-care skills. In addition, I am also a part of our county's assistive technology team where we provide adaptive equipment and a variety of technologies to help students function in school. I mostly work at Lewis and Clark, Caroline Middle School, and Caroline High School but you may see me at the other schools from time to time as well.

This is what I do, and I appreciate what you do! #OneCaroline

We wish Anna the best of luck as she enters the next phase of life !

post_text: The third and final phase of the Continuity of Instruction Plan is drawing to a close! All Tier II (Phase 3) assignments are due this Friday, May 15. Tier II (Phase 3) activities can be submitted via picture/email to teacher(s), sharing a google doc with instructors, through Schoology, or in hard copy at your student(s) school on Thursday, May 14 from 10am to 12pm or Friday, May 15 from 8am to 1pm.

post_text:
To increase WiFi access to the Caroline school community, Caroline County Public Schools has installed wireless access points at Caroline High School’s student parking lot. These access points will increase the internet availability to families during the COVID-19 pandemic and allow students to download and view the daily lessons created by teachers. This initiative enables students to continue to be engaged in the CCPS Continuity of Learning and remain connected with school staff.

http://ts.blogs.ccps.us/ccps-public-wi-fi/

Digital Footprint
It is important for your child to understand when they post on social media, they are leaving tracks. Take turns with your child searching your name and their name to see what digital footprint has been left. Talk about leaving the kind of footprint they can be proud of by being responsible online users.

post_text:
Happy School Nurse Appreciation Day! CCPS school nurses play an integral role in the health of our students and staff! On National School Nurse Day, we take special time to celebrate and recognize the contributions that NurseCox, Nurse Ryan, Nurse Tinder, Nurse Divelbliss, and Nurse Pettigrew are making to the health and learning of our children. These amazing health professionals lead the way to advance health and support education by ensuring that our students are safe, healthy & ready to learn.

Thank you! Thank you for nurturing our students with complex physical and mental health conditions, those at risk for health concerns, and students who are affected by societal issues. Your daily use of critical thinking and highly skilled, evidence-based practices help CCPS meet the needs of our students, families and school communities.

Fondly,
Dr. Calveric

post_text:
In recognition of Mental Health Awareness Month, we are spotlighting our current staff who support employee and student wellness. Today is Lynn Miller! Lynn is the Special Education Coordinator for Caroline County Public Schools. Most of her responsibilities include students who are in atypical placements such as private day schools, hospital programs, residential facilities, jail services, etc. She also represents CCPS on the Family Assessment Planning Team (FAPT) where they support at-risk youth and families by identifying their strengths/needs to help coordinate service plans. Lynn collaborates with the CSU, DSS, RACSB,CSA Coordinator, as well as other community stakeholders/organizations/agencies to help set up community based services and educational services.

This is what she does, and she appreciates what you do! #OneCaroline

post_text: In recognition of Mental Health Awareness Month, we are spotlighting our current staff who support employee and student wellness. Up first... I am Melissa White and have been with Caroline County Public Schools since 2001. I am the division's Special Education Transition Coordinator and assist students with disabilities and their families in obtaining services necessary to transition from high school to a post-secondary setting, whether for post-secondary education, employment, or long-term support of transition needs. Prior to this appointment, I was a CCPS Special Education Teacher for 7 years and a paraprofessional with Caroline for 6 years. I am the ESY Coordinator and serve on the Board of Directors for RACSB, Caroline’s Promise, and Caroline Chamber of Commerce. This is what I do, and I appreciate what you do! #OneCaroline

post_text: School Lunch Hero Day - LCES!
text: School Lunch Hero Day - LCES!

post_text:
Today is the eighth-annual "National School Lunch Hero Day," and CCPS has many food service blessings to be grateful for! Beyond our food service staff's "traditional" school year roles and responsibilities, our school nutrition women and men have been recently disguised as SUPER HEROES. Take a look at the data to prove it! Since the start of the COVID-19 K12 closure, our HEROES have manned eight school and community distribution sites and served over 45,696 "Grab and Go" meals to Caroline's youth! Such a critical service for our school and community families - #OneCaroline!

Whether you've been a recipient of a Grab and Go meal, eaten a healthy meal in one of the CCPS cafeterias, discussed your child/student's food allergies with a food service employee, or simply been greeted by their warm and supportive smiles, please take a moment to pause and praise today!

Happy National School Lunch Hero Day!

Dr. C

Take a look at the data to prove it! Since the start of the COVID-19 K12 closure, our HEROES have manned eight school and community distribution sites and served over 45,696 "Grab and Go" meals to Caroline's youth! Such a critical service for our school and community families - #OneCaroline!

Whether you've been a recipient of a Grab and Go meal, eaten a healthy meal in one of the CCPS cafeterias, discussed your child/student's food allergies with a food service employee, or simply been greeted by their warm and supportive smiles, please take a moment to pause and praise today!

Happy National School Lunch Hero Day!

Dr. C

post_text:
Create a Thankful Time Capsule

Materials: glass jar, paper, pencils and/or markers, a shovel, and a patch of ground (if you do not have a yard, you can leave the jar in a closet)

How to prepare the capsule: Cut paper into strips. Write the year on the end of the strip with marker, then write what you are thankful for. Have each member of your family do the same with their own strip. Roll up the notes and put into the jar.
Take a walk around your yard and think about where would be a good place to bury it. Dig a hole and place the capsule in the hole.

Dig it up the following year about the same time and add more things you are thankful for!

post_text:
Purple Up! for military kids day started with New Hampshire Operation: Military Kids as a way for everyone to show their support for military youth. Purple symbolizes "joint" in the military world, meaning "all services." In the world of color, if you combine Army green, Air Force blue, Marine red, and Navy blue, you get purple.

Purple also symbolizes:
-inner calm and feelings of self-worth and inspiration.
-knowledge, self-respect, dignity and wealth.

Today, CCPS celebrates our military students by wearing purple. Post a picture of you or your family wearing PURPLE!

post_text:
CLOTH FACE COVERINGS

Wearing a cloth face covering CORRECTLY can help prevent the spread of COVID-19 to others when you go out on essential trips.

Your cloth face covering should:

✔️ Reach above the nose, below the chin, and completely cover the mouth and nostrils

✔️ Fit snugly against the sides of the face

✔️ Be made of multiple layers of fabric that you can still breathe through

✔️ Be able to be laundered and machine dried without damaging the material or shape

If you have a child, remember those under age 2 should not wear a face covering.

Do not buy surgical masks to use as a face covering. Those are intended for healthcare workers and first responders. Many items you may already have in your home can be used to create face coverings.

Try creating a cloth face covering using bandanas, ski masks, washable napkins, or dish towels.

post_text:
Everyone reacts differently to stressful situations like COVID-19. You may feel anxious, mad, sad, or overwhelmed. Find ways to reduce your stress to help yourself and the people you care about.

Learn the common signs of stress. Make time to unwind and do activities you enjoy. Talk with family and friends by phone, text, or email. If you or a loved one is feeling overwhelmed, get support 24/7 by calling 1-800-985-5990 or text TalkWithUs to 66746.

post_text:
STOP THE SPREAD: You can help prevent the spread of respiratory illnesses like COVID-19 by following simple daily precautions.

Stay at home, if possible, if you are not sick.
Keep away from others who are sick.
Stay home if you are sick.
Due to increased susceptibility, older adults should keep away from others who are sick.
Limit close contact with others.
Wash your hands often.
Practice social distancing by putting space between yourself and others.
Clean and disinfect frequently used surfaces.
Avoid touching your face.

post_text:
Did you know... Approximately 2 million military children have experienced a parental deployment since 2001. There are currently 1.2 million military children of active duty members worldwide. Nearly 80% of military children attend public schools throughout the United States. The average military family moves three times more often than their civilian counterpart. The repeated and extended separations and increased hazards of deployment compound stressors in military children's lives. One-third of school-age military children show psychosocial behaviors such as being anxious, worrying often, crying more frequently.

CCPS supports our military families!

post_text: Congratulations!!!
shared_text:
Caroline's Promise is with Natasha David and 13 others.
April 9 at 2:06 PM ·

Caroline's Promise would like to congratulate Nhiya Dewer for being selected as the recipient for the 2020 Caroline’s Promise scholarship of $500.00 for fulfilling one or more of the Five Promises.

My name is Nhiya Dewer. I am a member of the National Honors Society, National Beta Club, Math Honor Society (Mu Alpha Theta), and completed over eighty hours of community service. I was a captain of varsity volleyball team for two years and ranked in the top three for girls tennis for three years. I attended the Governor’s World Language Academy where I became fluent in Spanish, and I will be the first student at CHS to graduate with a biliteracy seal. I plan to attend UVA in the fall and study Molecular biology to become a Neonatologist.

post_text: Congratulations!!!
shared_text:
Caroline's Promise is with Kaitlynn Baylor and 12 others.
April 9 at 12:30 PM ·

Caroline's Promise would like to congratulate Kara Rollins for being selected as the recipient for the 2020 Caroline’s Promise scholarship of $500.00 for fulfilling one of more of the Five Promises.

My name is Kara Rollins. I was a cheerleader at Caroline High School all four years, competition and sideline teams. I was also JV cheer captain my sophomore year and Varsity cheer captain my senior year. Working at the Bowling Green Health & Rehabilitation Center with my Nurse Aide class was one of the highlights of my senior year. Nurse Aide gave me the opportunity to make a difference in our community and an insight into what working in the healthcare field would be like. I plan to attend Old Dominion University this fall, with a major in Health Science and a concentration in Cytotechnology.

post_text: Congratulations!!!
shared_text:
Caroline's Promise is with Kaitlynn Baylor and 10 others.
April 9 at 10:54 AM ·

Caroline's Promise would like to congratulate Diontre Cephas for being selected as the recipient for the 2020 Caroline’s Promise scholarship of $500.00 for fulfilling one or more of the Five Promises.

My name is Diontre Cephas and I plan to attend North Carolina Central University majoring in Sports Medicine/Athletic Training.
I am a first generation college bound student for my family and I am very honored to receive this scholarship. Just like Malcolm X said (which I saw on Fresh Prince Of Bel Air) “Education is the passport to the future, for tomorrow belongs to those who prepare for it today.”
I want to make sure MY tomorrow is guaranteed for ME. This is my motto, that will encourage me throughout my college career.

post_text: Looking for more ways to include movement into your daily routine at home? See our latest Phase II resources below! Included is a “PE Choice Board” and several activity resources that correspond. Why should you include physical activity into your game plan, you say? It not only helps to promote strong bodies and healthy growth/development, but it also improves concentration, self-esteem, relieves stress, and improves sleep. MOVE IT, MOVE IT!

post_text: The ABCs of Gratitude. Have your child sit comfortably and close their eyes. Tell them to list things they are grateful for, beginning with “A” and working all the way through the alphabet to “Z.” Don’t be surprised if this exercise gets a little silly—it’s bound to get silly at some point, so just embrace it and enjoy the laughter with your child!

post_text:
UPDATE: We have a few EXCITING updates to share regarding our “Grab and Go” meal distribution process. First and foremost, “Grab and Go” meal distribution will continue over spring break and through the end of the school year. Additionally, we recently received USDA approval to begin serving meals on a Monday, Wednesday, and Friday schedule (see the flyer for times). Beginning Monday, April 6, each site will provide youth with two breakfast bags and two lunch bags (4 meals) per day. A new addition… this also includes meals for Saturday too! Finally, we have also been granted permission for adults to travel to the distribution site without the children in the vehicle. Parents traveling alone to a site should be prepared to provide each child’s name and age.

We hope these “Grab and Go” updates positively impact your family! A tremendous “SHOUT OUT” to our Food Service employees and Transportation team members who are making this service accessible to Caroline youth each and every day!
text:
UPDATE: We have a few EXCITING updates to share regarding our “Grab and Go” meal distribution process. First and foremost, “Grab and Go” meal distribution will continue over spring break and through the end of the school year. Additionally, we recently received USDA approval to begin serving meals on a Monday, Wednesday, and Friday schedule (see the flyer for times). Beginning Monday, April 6, each site will provide youth with two breakfast bags and two lunch bags (4 meals) per day. A new addition… this also includes meals for Saturday too! Finally, we have also been granted permission for adults to travel to the distribution site without the children in the vehicle. Parents traveling alone to a site should be prepared to provide each child’s name and age.

We hope these “Grab and Go” updates positively impact your family! A tremendous “SHOUT OUT” to our Food Service employees and Transportation team members who are making this service accessible to Caroline youth each and every day!

For families needing paper packets, please visit your child’s school for curbside pickup on Wednesday, 4/1 or Thursday, 4/2 between 8:00-1:00. Phase II materials provide two weeks of activities for April 14-April 24 (No Work Over Spring Break, 4/3-4/13). (Travel and Pickup Permitted in Governor’s Executive Order)

post_text:
Good afternoon, CCPS families! This afternoon, Governor Northam issued a statewide "stay at home" order through June 10. Thank you for supporting this aggressive public health measure during this time.

While additional CCPS updates will be provided in the near future, we did want to highlight two brief items that may be on your mind... Grab and Go meals and Phase II of the Continuity of Instruction plan. The order permits/supports K12 institutions with continuing to serve breakfast and lunch meals to youth 18 and under. Additionally, Phase II instructional materials (for use after spring break, 4/14-4/27) will be available online and for curbside pickup on April 1st and 2nd. Those without Internet are able to pick up packets between 8:00 a.m.-1:00 p.m. These hours parallel the food distribution hours and will enable you to grab "Grab and Go" meals as well as packets.

In the interim, please take a look at the tremendous amount of closure information located on the Virginia Department of Education's website. http://www.doe.virginia.gov/

Stay well,
Sarah Calveric, Ph.D.
Superintendent
text:

Additionally, Phase II instructional materials (for use after spring break, 4/14-4/27) will be available online and for curbside pickup on April 1st and 2nd. Those without Internet are able to pick up packets between 8:00 a.m.-1:00 p.m. These hours parallel the food distribution hours and will enable you to grab "Grab and Go" meals as well as packets.

In the interim, please take a look at the tremendous amount of closure information located on the Virginia Department of Education's website. http://www.doe.virginia.gov/

Sarah Calveric, Ph.D.

post_text:
While we continue to adjust our daily lives in response to the global health crisis, we find ourselves feeling a sense of gratitude that extends well beyond our CCPS walls. Today we were able to serve 1,040 “Grab and Go” meals to 520 Caroline youth. Because of our collaboration with community sites, church volunteers, building staff, the sheriff’s office, the food services department, and the transportation department, we provided curbside assistance to our Caroline families. [ 211 more words ]

post_text:
Volunteers and Athletes,

It is with a heavy heart that the decision has been made to cancel our 2020 Special Olympics Meet in the Middle. The CDC has provided guidance that large events consisting of 50 people or more should be cancelled for the next 8 weeks to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Caroline County Public Schools will be following this recommendation in order to keep our students and volunteers healthy.
Thank you to everyone who has volunteered their efforts to plan this event. Your efforts are most appreciated! Caroline County will continue to work with Special Olympics to plan this event for the 2020-21 school year.
Thank you,
Lora Glass
Director of Special Olympics

post_text: UPDATE: CCPS is excited to partner with our community to add three community-based "Grab & Go" meal sites. CCPS will begin serving breakfast/lunch meals on Tuesday, 3/17-Friday, 3/27 (no weekends) at BGES, LCES, MES, and CMS. We will also be serving meals at Second Mount Zion Baptist Church (Dawn), Port Royal Town Hall (Port Royal), and Upper Caroline Fire Dept. (Woodford). We hope our Caroline families who live farthest from school "Grab & Go" sites will find these locations more accessible. Thank you to our community site hosts and Second Mount Zion, Wright's Chapel, Spotswood at Ladysmith,and Oxford Mount Zion for supporting these efforts with additional volunteers. Shout out to our School Nutrition Department for caring for our Caroline youth during the COVID-19 closure. #OneCaroline #BeWell

We will also be serving meals at Second Mount Zion Baptist Church (Dawn), Port Royal Town Hall (Port Royal), and Upper Caroline Fire Dept. (Woodford). post_text:
Calendar Adjustment for Caroline County Public Schools

In recognition of the mild winter season and resulting unused inclement weather days, the School Board approved the following 19-20 calendar revisions at the March 9, 2020 School Board meeting.

The School Board voted to make Friday, April 3rd a student and staff holiday. This is the Friday before Spring break. In addition, the school board decided to make Tuesday, May 19th the last day of school for students.

We are excited about the School Board’s opportunity to provide these additional school holidays. CCPS will also capitalize on these changes to conduct extensive facility cleaning on Friday, March 13th and Friday, April 3rd.
text:
Calendar Adjustment for Caroline County Public Schools

In recognition of the mild winter season and resulting unused inclement weather days, the School Board approved the following 19-20 calendar revisions at the March 9, 2020 School Board meeting.

The School Board voted to make Friday, April 3rd a student and staff holiday. This is the Friday before Spring break. In addition, the school board decided to make Tuesday, May 19th the last day of school for students.

We are excited about the School Board’s opportunity to provide these additional school holidays. CCPS will also capitalize on these changes to conduct extensive facility cleaning on Friday, March 13th and Friday, April 3rd.

post_text:
LCES Student Vs. Staff Basketball Game
Thursday, February 27th
6:00-7:30 PM
Caroline Middle School Gymnasium

WHAT IS IT? Twenty 5th grade students of Lewis and Clark will face off versus teachers from all
grade levels, administrators and school support staff. The LCES Dance team will perform at half
time. All students and their families are invited and encouraged to come be a part of this fun
filled event! Doors open at 5:30 PM and the game starts at 6:00 PM.

WHY? The PE department is sponsoring this event in correlation with Kid’s Heart Challenge to
raise awareness and funds for heart health and research. All money raised will go to the
American Heart Association.

ADMISSION: $3 for adults
$2 for children
FREE for any student who raised money for Kid’s Heart Challenge!

RAFFLE: Raffle tickets are $1 each OR 6 tickets for $5.

Prize packs include: The Mix House, MS Terrell & Sons, Delta Prime Fitness, Flying Squirrels,
Fredericksburg Nationals, Kings Dominion, Lularoe, The Timbers, Savannah Spieldenner
Photography, Pampered Chef, Scentsy, 31, EM Dodgers, YMCA and MORE!

Middle School Conditioning and Tryout Information (This information has been available on The Buzz and CMS Athletic Blog – http://cmsathletics.blogs.ccps.us/ )

All students must have an Athletic Physical on file to tryout. Students with 2 F’s on their report cards from the 2nd 9 weeks are ineligible to try out. Eligibility will be reevaluated at end of 3rd 9 weeks. Activity bus forms can also be found on the CMS Athletic Blog

Baseball: Coach Glenn Schott
Conditioning – Starting Feb 24th conditioning will run after school Monday – Thursday from 3- 5:15pm.
Tryouts – Begin March 2nd

Softball: Coach “Nikki” Caitlyn O’Callaghan
Conditioning – Tuesdays and Thursdays from 3 – 5:15pm
Tryouts – Begin March 2nd

Girls Soccer: Sharon Swanton
Conditioning – Wednesday’s from 3 – 5:15pm
Tryouts – Begin March 2nd

Track: Coach Marcellus Harris
Tryouts – Begins Feb 24th from 3 – 5:15pm (practice is over at HS Track)

Volleyball Skills Club: Coach Clay Forehand
Resumes Feb 25th and Feb 27th. 3 – 5:15pm

Cheer: Selina Fields
Tryouts begin March 3rd – March 5th – Forms can be found on Athletic Blog.

post_text:
CCPS Board adopts calendar for 2020-21 school year The Caroline County School Board voted Monday, February 10, 2020, to adopt a calendar for the 2020-21 school year that includes: Two-week winter break (3 weekends) Full week spring break (plus Friday before) 3 Day Thanksgiving break A shortened School Day (15min. reduction to the end of the school day) After receiving input from multiple stakeholder groups and an online survey, the school division’s calendar committee made revisions to the initially proposed calendar and requested approval from the school board. [ 148 more words ]
https://www.ccps.us/2020/02/approved-2020-2021-instructional-calendar/

post_text:
Everyone has a favorite teacher who helped shape who they are today. Tell us in your own words (a letter, a poem or an essay) about the teacher who influenced and inspired you the most—from kindergarten to now for a chance to win $5,000 for the teacher and $5,000 for the school.

Who Can Participate:
High School Students age 14 years and older.

Here's How It Works:
Students write an essay, poem, or thank-you letter (500 words or less, in English) sharing how a teacher has influenced their life and why they appreciate and admire them. Entries can be submitted online through this page or at their local Barnes & Noble store.

This contest is open during the month of February, from 2/1-2/29.

What Teachers Get:
The winner of the "Barnes & Noble Teacher of the Year" award will receive $5,000 and will be recognized at a special event at a Barnes & Noble store. The winning teacher's school will receive $5,000 as well.

post_text:
Congratulations to Mrs. Kristi Thomas, BGES Reading Specialist, who was recognized today by Virginia Association of Supervision and Curriculum Development (VASCD) as one of seven 2020 Impact Leaders. Superintendent Calveric, the State Secretary of Education, and the VASCD Board recognized Mrs. Thomas for her transformational leadership at Bowling Green ES. While Kristi’s impact is far reaching, she has been instrumental in the creation of the Honorable Husky Program, a book vending machine, and Hush Little Huskies reading program.

Congratulations, Mrs. Thomas! VASCD, CCPS, and BGES are proud of your accomplishments and commitment to students and staff.

Congratulations CHS Senior Betas!
At the Virginia Senior Beta Convention in Hampton, VA, Caroline High School students were amazing! Congratulations to everyone who participated in a test, competition or skit. You all worked incredibly hard, and it showed!

The following CHS Betas join the winners from the Virginia Beta Leadship Summit and are National Beta Convention bound!

Jonathan Parker-NEW VA State Beta Secretary
Laila Amshoff-1st Place Visual Arts-Jewelry Division I

Ainsley Newcomb-2nd Place 10th Grade Language Arts
Jaidyn Davis, Neveah Echezona, Emily Gillespie, Tkai Jackson, Sara Migliorini & Jordan Rollins-Williams-2nd Place Campaign Skit (for Jonathan’s Campaign)
Geaninna Luciano-3rd Place 12th Grade Spanish
Micah Pugh-3rd Place 11th Grade Social Studies

post_text:
Caroline County Public Schools Welcomes New Special Education Coordinator, Lynn Miller!

Caroline County Public Schools is excited to announce Mrs. Lynn Miller as the new Special Education Coordinator for the division. Lynn Miller was a Career Switcher after 10 years in banking. Lynn started teaching in Caroline County at Caroline High School, where she taught Special Education Algebra, Geometry, and Algebra Functions and Data. After four years at the high school, Mrs. Miller served as CCPS Special Education Coordinator before taking a position with King William County Public Schools.

After four years with King William County Public Schools, Mrs. Miller is returning to what she feels is home in her previous position as Special Education Coordinator. Her education started at Old Dominion University with a BS in Psychology, followed by a Master’s of Education in Special Education from University of Phoenix, and most recently an Education Specialist degree from Liberty University. CCPS welcomes Lynn Miller back to Caroline!

CHS Tryouts for Boys & Girls Soccer, Baseball, Softball, Boys & Girls Tennis, and Track & Field will begin on Monday, 2/24. If you are interested in playing a sport then you should make plans to stay after school. You must have a valid, completed VHSL Sports Physical in order to try out for a team. Please make arrangements to have your ride at CHS to pick you up at 5:30. Activity buses will be running Monday-Thursday during spring sports and will leave at 5:30 each day from CHS.

MES PTA Family Movie Night
Date: Friday, February 21st

Time: 5:00 – 8:00 pm

Featuring: Disney’s Live Action Aladdin

Gather up the whole family and join us for a viewing of Aladdin! Admission is FREE. Our concession stand will sell pizza, hot dogs, popcorn, candy, drinks and more throughout the movie. Doors will open at 5:00 pm. The movie will begin at 5:30 pm. See you there!

Gather up the whole family and join us for a viewing of Aladdin! Admission is FREE. Our concession stand will sell pizza, hot dogs, popcorn, candy, drinks and more throughout the movie. Doors will open at 5:00 pm. The movie will begin at 5:30 pm. See you there!

post_text: CCPS is monitoring the statewide flu concerns and is taking a number of precautions to maintain a healthy and safe environment for our students and staff. We encourage students to wash hands, avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth, and stay home if you are sick. Our staff regularly cleans and disinfects surfaces in the schools such as water fountains, door handles, furniture, and restrooms. Classrooms are treated with a deep clean machine to be proactive during this time of year. Additionally, CCPS is also monitoring daily attendance and has not identified any trends similar to some of our neighboring school divisions. Thanks for your support in keeping our school community healthy! If you have any suggestions or ideas on how to prevent illness at your child’s school, please contact the school office.

post_text:
Garland Gravatt Community Service Award

Cornelius Black, CHS Technical Drawing Teacher and Archie Roberts, CHS Carpentry Teacher, will be honored at the Habitat for Humanity Build the Love Event on February 3rd as recipients of the first ever Garland Gravatt Community Service Award. Mr. Gravatt was one of the founding members of Caroline County Habitat for Humanity who had a love and passion for serving his community. These awards are given to community members who build community and hope through their jobs or volunteer service.
Mr. Roberts will be recognized for his leadership of the CTE carpentry class who helped build Caroline Habitat’s first round of Self-help Builds. Mr. Roberts and the student’s efforts have been essential to the Habitat for Humanity success. Mr. Black’s leadership and heart for his students was an essential ingredient in the success of the builds. Both Mr. Roberts and Mr. Black will be recognized for their participation and efforts on the Caroline County Habitat for Humanity first Self-Help Builds. Congratulations!

post_text: This Friday we celebrate Joshua Just, Principal of Caroline High School! Mr. Just attended Bethany College in West Virginia. In addition to being the Athletic Director of Hanover High School, he has been an administrator for 4 years in Hanover and Caroline. His favorite thing about his staff is that CHS has a family atmosphere. Mr. Just loves the different personalities of his of students at CHS and his top accomplishment in his career is serving the students as their Principal. CCPS thanks you Mr. Just for all you do!

post_text: Happy Principal's Appreciation week to Madison Elementary School Principal Teresa Hicks! Teresa is a proud graduate of Caroline High School. She also attended VCU and UVA. Ms. Hicks has been in administration for the past 4.5 years. Her favorite thing about her staff is that they are a family, they embrace each other's strengths, and they support each other on a daily basis. Principal Hicks states her students are respectful, responsible, and ready for learning each and every day. CCPS is so excited to have one of our own leading Madison Elementary School!

post_text:
As we continue to celebrate our CCPS Principals, today is Lewis and Clark Elementary School Principal Cyndi Brown's time to shine! Mrs. Brown attended the University of Pittsburgh as an undergraduate and George Mason University for her Master's Degree. She has been the LCES Principal for 6 years and was also an Assistant Principal for 8 years.

Mrs. Brown's favorite things about her staff are their collaboration and high expectations. She loves the students' smiles and excitement when learning, and that they are not afraid to take risks to extend their thinking. Principal Brown is also excited about their cohesive attitudes, love for being a Great Grizzly, and student participation in LCES activities!

She would like to share that over the last 5 years, LCES has continued to make gains in all academic areas and in all student subgroups. The school is striving to be a Blue Ribbon School. At LCES, they continue to dream, create, and inspire to be sure their students are having fun with their learning.

post_text:
As we continue to celebrate Principal's Appreciation Week at CCPS, today we will spotlight Cynthia Heckstall - Principal of Bowling Green Elementary School!

Ms. Heckstall attended VCU and has been a principal/assistant principal for 12 years. She is excited about BGES, because she feels her staff is patient, caring, engaging and able to build positive relationships. Her favorite things about BGE students are that they are resilient, respectful, responsible and positive.

Under Ms. Heckstall's leadership, BGES is working hard to build leaders amongst students to staff. The school has truly embraced the concept of One School, One Team, One Family!

post_text: COURTNEY RAYNORE, a Kindergarten teacher at LCES, uses some very unique tricks in her classroom to help students manage time, instruction and behavior. The "Kindergarten Tribe" in Ms. Raynore's classroom is a calm, positive and magical woodlands environment where students learn through imagination in a clutter-free space. A kind fairy named "Sunflower" watches them as they learn. The more they learn kindness, love and curriculum, the more magical she becomes....leaving notes and special treats. Ms. Raynore also uses chimes to redirect her tribe when their voices get too loud in the woodlands. Each day her students can earn shots in a student vs. teacher basketball game for quiet, smooth transitions from stations and lining up. Also, tickets can be earned for the treasure box when demonstrating random acts of kindness in the classroom.

Congratulations to the Cavalier Swim Team for a great meet on January 10, 2020!
Several CHS swimmers placed in their events against Spotsylvania HS.
Sean Kenny placed 2nd in the 200 free
Dakota DiAscro placed 3rd in the 200 IM and the 100 backstroke
Damien Smith placed 3rd in the 50 freestyle
Butler Frank placed 3rd in the 100 freestyle and the 100 breaststroke
Caroline Hale placed first in the 50 freestyle and the 100 butterfly
Kaylin Waldron placed second in the 50 freestyle
Ellie Nichols placed 3rd in the 100 backstroke
Gracen Kelley placed 2nd in the 500 freestyle and 1st in the 100 breaststroke.
The Girls A 200 freestyle relay, consisting of Kaylin Waldron, Jayda Anderson, Ellie Nichols, and Caroline Hale, also placed first.
Great Job CAVS!!

post_text:
We will be spotlighting our Principals this week in honor of Principal's Appreciation Week!

Up first is Mr. Darin Thompson, Principal of CMS! Mr. Thompson graduated from VCU with a degree in Criminal Justice, a Master's in Public Administration, and a Master's in Education from Regent University. He is pursuing a Doctorate in Educational Leadership. This is his fourth year as a Principal with two previous years as Assistant Principal.

Mr. Thompson is impressed by the level of his staff members’ dedication to the success of all CMS students, and he loves the fact that his students have a tremendous amount of school spirit. Mr. Thompson would like to celebrate the areas of growth that CMS has been able to demonstrate with respect to gap group performance on recent assessments.

CCPS is honored to call Mr. Thompson one of our own!

On behalf of Dr. Calveric and the Senior Leadership Team, the board is pleased to announce that Caroline County Public Schools will celebrate January 20-26 as Principal's Appreciation Week. The role of the Principal as the instructional leader is critically important to ensure students have access to high quality teaching and learning experiences. Our principals work diligently to help students and teachers excel, and their leadership and hard work are essential to the success of our schools. Please take a moment to thank your Principal this week!
https://www.ccps.us/2020/01/principal-appreciation-month/

post_text:
Are You Interested in the National Junior Honor Society?
The National Junior Honor Society is an organization that promotes appropriate recognition for members show outstanding accomplishments in the areas of scholarship, leadership, character, service, and citizenship.
Interest Forms for NJHS are now available and can be picked up in the 7th-grade guidance office starting on January 10, 2020. 7th grade students with a cumulative Grade Point Average (GPA) of at least a 3.5 are eligible to apply for membership.
All Interest Forms and documentation must be turned in by February 28, 2020.

post_text: On December 24, the CMS basketball team went to the Bowling Green Nursing Home to play bingo with the residents. This was the 4th year that the players, along with Coach Minor, have given back to the community by participating in this event. They spent an hour or two playing numerous games of bingo, helping the residents find numbers on their cards, and calling out for them when they won. It was an event filled with laughter and good times. Thank you to Coach Minor and the team for being a part of this get-together.

post_text:
Elizabeth Cierra Dosado, daughter of James and Celina Dosado, was selected as Student of the Month for December at Caroline High School. Elizabeth was selected because of her determination, hard work, and successes both in and out of the classroom. She is in the top 3% of her graduating class and has maintained a GPA over a 4.0 throughout high school. Perhaps she is best known around CHS for her wrestling achievements. Elizabeth is a member of the varsity wrestling team where she has been a two time state qualifier, the Hanover Hawkeye Wrestling Team where she was a seven time VAWA champion, and the Virginia National Wrestling Team where she was a two time national placer. Elizabeth is the first wrestler from Caroline to make it onto the state team. She also enjoys singing, writing, and helping others through church, mission trips, and working with Special Olympics.

After graduation, Elizabeth plans to attend a four year university to become a psychologist or mental health counselor as well as a wrestling coach.

It was an honor to observe all Caroline County elected officials being sworn in for the January 1, 2020-December 31, 2023 term. A special congratulations to our CCPS school board members: Nancy Carson, John Copeland, Shawn Kelley, Dr. JoWanda Rollins-Fells, George Spaulding, and Calvin Taylor.

post_text: We have an amazing group of parents and educators who serve on the Gifted Advisory Committee! This team meets each quarter to review the Gifted Local Plan, provides feedback and recommendations that enhance our program. Meetings are collaborative and engaging. During this meeting members participated in a point of view protocol regarding the social emotional responses of the gifted student followed by research and reflections.

post_text: Teamwork makes the dream work! We are ready for the Caroline Senior Gala tonight at CHS! Looking forward to hosting over 350 seniors (62 years of age and up). JROTC students will escort our guests into the gala, Divas with Promise and Men of Valor will provide supports throughout the evening, and the culinary students are prepping dinner as we post! Shout out to the Board of Supervisors for their monetary support, Caroline’s Promise, Fox Insurance, CCPS, Chamber of Commerce, YMCA, Rotary, and 21st Century Classic for planning and implementation. #OneCaroline

post_text: Yesterday was the Cavalier Clash Wrestling Tournament hosted at CHS. Out of 13 weight classes, CHS had winners in 11 of them and finished in FIRST place for team points. Beyond this achievement, the referees awarded the CHS wrestling team with the SPORTSMANSHIP AWARD. The Cavs cheered on each teammate, coached when needed, and were simply kind and encouraging. #OneCaroline #GrowingProgram #CHSPride
